notes.title: Core Models: Lasswell, Shannon–Weaver, SMCR
notes.content: Master the linear models most frequently asked: Lasswell's 5W (Who says What, in Which channel, to Whom, with What effect), Shannon–Weaver's technical model (source–encoder–channel–noise–decoder–receiver) and Berlo's SMCR. Know strengths, limits, and typical exam contrasts (linear vs. interactive; engineering vs. socio-cultural views).
keyTakeaways: Lasswell emphasizes effects and functions; great for propaganda/PR questions.
Shannon–Weaver introduces 'noise' and information capacity; cite 1948/49 papers.
SMCR expands on source/message/channel/receiver variables (skills, content).

resources.title: Shannon (1948) — A Mathematical Theory of Communication

notes.title: Agenda-Setting, Framing & Priming (High-Yield Theory Set)
notes.content: Differentiate agenda-setting (media tell us what to think about) from framing (how to think about it) and priming (criteria for evaluation). Use classic Chapel Hill study and contemporary applications to elections and issue salience.
keyTakeaways: Agenda-setting is repeatedly asked; support with 1972 McCombs & Shaw.
Tie to Pakistan: news agendas during elections/policy debates.
Contrast with uses and gratifications in application-style answers.

notes.title: Two-Step Flow & Opinion Leadership
notes.content: Explain why media influence is often mediated by opinion leaders (Katz & Lazarsfeld). Use modern analogues (influencers, WhatsApp admins) for Pakistan-centric examples.
keyTakeaways: Great for compare/contrast with hypodermic needle.
Use Decatur study as evidence; cite opinion leadership in digital networks.
Connect to misinformation correction via trusted intermediaries.

notes.title: 'Global Village', Media Determinism & Cultural Imperialism
notes.content: Use McLuhan's 'medium is the message' and 'global village' in globalization answers; contrast with cultural imperialism critiques; bring local examples (Pakistani TV/streaming, TikTok bans, dubbing/subbing cultures).
keyTakeaways: Define technological determinism vs. socio-cultural agency.
Relate to localization ('glocalisation') and resistance.
Tie to policy (PEMRA codes, streaming regulation debates).

notes.title: History of Pakistani Journalism: Muslim Press to PBC/PTV
notes.content: Trace key milestones: Muslim League papers; Dawn's founding by Jinnah; Nawa-i-Waqt and movement journalism; Radio Pakistan's 1947 broadcast; conversion to Pakistan Broadcasting Corporation in 1972; PBC Act, 1973; private channels after PEMRA (2002).
keyTakeaways: Use names/dates: Dawn (1941 Delhi; Jinnah); Nawa-i-Waqt (1940; Hameed Nizami).
Radio Pakistan became PBC via 1972 ordinance and PBC Act 1973.
Anchor history answers with primary institutional sites.

notes.title: News: Definitions, Values & Functions
notes.content: Cover news values (timeliness, significance, proximity, prominence, conflict, novelty, human interest), roles (inform, watchdog, mobilize), and structure (inverted pyramid vs. narrative leads).
keyTakeaways: Use 'news as the soul of journalism' framing—asked repeatedly.
Give Pakistan examples (budget, SC verdicts, disaster coverage).
Always show headline/lead/nut-graf skills in answers.

notes.title: Reporting & Editing Practice (Leads, Headlines, Backgrounders)
notes.content: Contrast straight vs. feature leads; banner headline conventions; backgrounders and explainers; ensure source triage and fact-checks in workflows.
keyTakeaways: MCQ favorites: banner headline, byline, backgrounder, dateline.
Practice rewriting weak leads and condensing backgrounders.
Use credible sourcing (PID/ECP/Finance Division) for data stories.

notes.title: Media Laws (Pakistan): PEMRA, PECA, PCP, Defamation
notes.content: Know core media statutes: PEMRA Ordinance (2002) for broadcast licensing/regulation; PECA (2016) for electronic crimes; Press Council of Pakistan Ordinance (2002) and Ethical Code; provincial/ICT defamation laws; Article 19 & 19-A (freedom & access to information).
keyTakeaways: Quote exact law names and years; cite specific sections where relevant.
Differentiate content regulation (PEMRA) from cyber-crime (PECA).
Tie Article 19/19-A to RTI and public interest journalism.

resources.title: Press Council of Pakistan Ordinance (Code in Schedule)

notes.title: Self-Regulation & Industry Bodies: APNS, CPNE, PID
notes.content: Understand roles: APNS (publishers; circulation, dues, ads), CPNE (editors; press freedom advocacy), PID (official information arm). Use them in ethics/industry structure answers.
keyTakeaways: APNS notices and accreditation affect ad flows.
CPNE foregrounds editorial independence and safety.
PID is the government's principal information department.

notes.title: Press Freedom & Safety: RSF, CPJ, PPF
notes.content: Use RSF World Press Freedom Index and CPJ/PPF briefings for evidence on safety, impunity, and constraints; quote Pakistan's ranking/year trends when asked.
keyTakeaways: Always date the index (e.g., RSF 2024/2025) and use exact rank when known.
Use CPJ country alerts for recent safety context.
PPF provides local documentation and training resources.

notes.title: Right of Access to Information (RTI) & Article 19-A
notes.content: Explain how RTI frameworks enable investigative reporting; tie to federal/provincial RTI laws and procedures for requests; combine with ethics (public interest tests).
keyTakeaways: Use RTI case examples (budgets, procurement, environment).
Link to watchdog role and development journalism.
Integrate with newsroom source protection protocols.

notes.title: Ethics: Codes, Defamation & Online Journalism
notes.content: Compare press codes (PCP Schedule) with platform policies; map defamation, privacy, contempt, hate-speech considerations; write exam-style 'ideal code' outlines.
keyTakeaways: Use PCP Ethical Code language in answers for credibility.
Balance 'freedom vs. responsibility' with case examples.
Note online corrections/archives policy and transparency.

notes.title: Broadcast & Electronic Media: From PTV/PBC to Private Channels
notes.content: Survey evolution of electronic media; regulatory environment (PEMRA); public service mandates vs. commercial imperatives; use development communication examples (PSAs, floods, polio).
keyTakeaways: Use PBC timeline; distinguish statutory mandates from private regulation.
Discuss content quotas, licensing, and code enforcement.
Tie to social impact: education, health, disaster response.

notes.title: Development Communication & DSC
notes.content: Differentiate classic 'development journalism' from Development Support Communication (problem-solving campaigns: health, education, climate). Integrate diffusion of innovations (adoption curve) in design answers.
keyTakeaways: State objectives, stakeholders, channels, metrics.
Use Pakistan caselets (polio, dengue, floods).
Discuss audience segmentation & message testing.

resources.title: UNESCO — Model Curricula for Journalism Education

notes.title: Political Communication: Propaganda, PR & Spin
notes.content: Contrast propaganda models (hypodermic needle legacy) with contemporary political PR and media effects; explain agenda-building and media management in elections.
keyTakeaways: Link to ethics (transparency, labeling, advertorials).
Use examples of pressers, manifestos, televised debates.
Discuss watchdog vs. access journalism tension.

notes.title: Public Relations (PRO, PID) — Tools & Ethics
notes.content: Define PR vs. personal assistant roles; tools (press release, briefing, media kit, crisis comms, stakeholder mapping); discuss state PR (PID) vs. corporate PR; evaluate 'spin doctor' criticism.
keyTakeaways: MCQs often test PRO duties and tools.
In essays, add measurement (outcomes vs. outputs).
Crisis comms templates score highly (holding statement, Q&A).

notes.title: Advertising: Principles, Formats & Regulation
notes.content: Cover creative brief, AIDA, media planning basics; distinguish print vs. electronic vs. digital units; discuss puffery, deception rules, and ad clearance in Pakistan (APNS).
keyTakeaways: Integrate ethics and consumer protection.
Use examples (public service vs. commercial campaigns).
Know APNS role in agency/client accreditation and dues.

notes.title: Ethics, Safety & Social Media Regulation (Recent)
notes.content: Summarize recent debates on amendments/regulations affecting social media, disinformation, and journalist safety; cite watchdog reactions (PFUJ, CPJ, RSF).
keyTakeaways: Support with current, dated examples from 2024–2025.
Balance harms (fake news) vs. free expression concerns.
Connect to PECA and due-process safeguards.

notes.title: Development Journalism vs. DSC (Compare & Contrast)
notes.content: Classic development journalism is reportage on development issues; DSC designs communication to solve specific problems. Use matrices (objectives, channels, metrics).
keyTakeaways: Add diffusion/innovation adopters to DSC answers.
Show evaluation plan (baseline, KAP, outcome).
Localize with health/education/wash projects.

notes.title: Global News Agencies & International Media
notes.content: Review wire services (Reuters, AP, AFP), CNN effect, news flow and imbalance debates (MacBride Commission).
keyTakeaways: MCQs test agency acronyms & origins.
Use MacBride to discuss NWICO & media flows.
Relate to Pakistan's reliance on wires for foreign news.

resources.title: MacBride Commission (context)
resources.description: Use as entry to global media issues; pair with textbooks

notes.title: Digital Journalism: Verification, Disinfo & OSINT Basics
notes.content: Outline verification checklists (provenance, source, date, location), reverse image/video basics, geolocation cues; apply to elections and crisis coverage.
keyTakeaways: Always document source trails and corrections policy.
Include safety & legal considerations (PECA, defamation).
Use newsroom SOPs and checklists.

notes.title: Data Journalism & Public Records (Pakistan)
notes.content: Show how to use public datasets (Finance Division budget PDFs, SBP, PBS, ECP) for explanatory and watchdog reporting; design simple story pitches from official numbers.
keyTakeaways: Always cite and link the exact table/report version.
Include a small visualization plan in answers (chart type, caveat).
Build reproducible notes (date, source, method).

notes.title: Normative Theories of the Press
notes.content: Summarize authoritarian, libertarian, social responsibility, Soviet/communist, development media, democratic-participant. Apply to Pakistan's mixed media environment.
keyTakeaways: Map theory to policy tools (licensing, codes, market).
Use recent regulatory debates to illustrate social responsibility claims.
Include a critique (ownership, economics, capture).

notes.title: Media Economics & Commercialism in News
notes.content: Explain revenue models (ads, subscriptions, branded content), commercialization pressures, and impact on news values; discuss conflict of interest and transparency.
keyTakeaways: Relate commercial pressures to sensationalism and 'ratings wars'.
Propose newsroom firewalls and disclosures.
Use APNS circulars to show ad-market governance.

notes.title: Press Organizations & Movement History
notes.content: Revise Muslim Press role in Pakistan Movement; key editors and newspapers; link to state formation narrative.
keyTakeaways: Use Dawn & Nawa-i-Waqt histories to cite specifics.
Tie to exam essays on 'freedom of press vs. responsibility'.
Connect early press roles to contemporary watchdog claims.

notes.title: Exam Skills: Model Answers, Comparatives & MCQ Bank
notes.content: Build outlines that compare theories (e.g., Hypodermic vs. Two-step; Agenda-setting vs. Framing). Maintain a running MCQ sheet of definitions, dates, laws, acronyms.
keyTakeaways: Always date stats (index ranks, law years).
Use at least one primary law/report per long answer.
Practice 3–4 theory comparisons with Pakistan examples.

notes.title: PEMRA Codes & Content Standards
notes.content: Summarize content standards (news/current affairs, decency, children, hate speech, election coverage); explain complaints, show-cause, fines, and appeal routes.
keyTakeaways: Distinguish license conditions vs. content code provisions.
Connect with due process and editorial SOPs.
Use examples (tickers, crawlers, tick-tock coverage).

notes.title: Cybercrime, Defamation & Online Harms: PECA in Practice
notes.content: Outline offences (unauthorised access, data interference, cyberstalking), procedures and safeguards; compare criminal PECA with civil defamation; add safety tips for reporters.
keyTakeaways: Quote PECA sections sparingly but accurately.
Map jurisdiction, investigation (FIA) and trial processes.
Address chilling effects vs. legitimate harms.

notes.title: Journalist Safety: Policy, Practice & Case Context
notes.content: Use CPJ alerts, RSF ranks, and PPF reports for up-to-date safety context; add field protocols (risk assessment, hostile environment awareness, digital hygiene).
keyTakeaways: Cite recent, dated examples to demonstrate awareness.
Include safety checklist in practical answers.
Note legal support hotlines/networks where relevant.

notes.title: Journalism Education: Curricula & Emerging Skills
notes.content: Align prep with UNESCO model curricula (ethics, data, AI literacy); propose personal learning plan for CSS: theory refreshers, law quick-ref, MCQ drills, and model answers.
keyTakeaways: Integrate AI/verification modules (source evaluation).
Balance theory with Pakistan law and case content.
Use a revision grid mapping 'year×topic' repeats.
